issue.title: std::expected<T,E>::value() & assumes E is copy constructible

discussion.blockquote: Throws: bad_expected_access(error()) if has_value() is false.
discussion.p: But if error() returns a reference to a move-only type then it can't be copied and the function body is ill-formed. Should it be constrained with is_copy_constructible_v<E>? Or just mandate it?
Similarly, the value()&& and value() const&& overloads require is_move_constructible_v<E> to be true for bad_expected_access(std::move(error())) to be valid.

blockquote.pre: constexpr const T& value() const &; constexpr T& value() &;

blockquote.p: -8- Returns: val, if has_value() is true.
-9- Throws: bad_expected_access(error()) if has_value() is false.

blockquote.pre: constexpr T&& value() &&; constexpr const T&& value() const &&;

blockquote.p: -10- Returns: std::move(val), if has_value() is true.
-11- Throws: bad_expected_access(std::move(error())) if has_value() is false.
